If the winter surface does not allow hill running/running training, then you convert the session into some fartlek. If you run the hill on a treadmill (which is perfectly fine), you can add the running training to another session that you run outside. (Tuesday or Saturday, because it's difficult to do running training on a treadmill)

Hope you find the right one, and don't be "frightened" by the slope. You will get tired, but certainly not exhausted. The hill gives the best effect if you run just right in the early period we are in now!! If you do everything on that pass, it is easy to burn both the psyche and also physically. See the training as a big whole, and then no individual sessions must be too tough!

On Sunday, there will be an adjustment in the program with a brand new session that the coach calls marathon tweezers. The target image is that the session should provide long-distance volume, but that you collect the volume via 16 x 1 km at a slightly faster pace than your planned average speed on the marathon.

The goal of the session is that you will work on your oxygen uptake (fitness) in a gentle way at the same time that you are both physically and mentally training to hold on for a long time at a higher speed than a long session pace.

Feel your marathon pace in the distance workout today. 1 km calmly at first and then the goal is a full 10 km at your intended marathon pace; if everything feels ok and the surface/temperature is suitable for running.

Doesn't want the body; then you take 10-12 km at your leisurely pace for the day.

Two new elements in the training program in today's session.

The main element "Long hill"

Running strength and the technique element running training.

Warm up with a distance jog to a hill you know. The slope should not be "too steep" but nicely runnable all the way. If it is "wintery ground" you can adapt accordingly and run calmly and also do the run training calmly.

After the warm-up, you do some light mobility and then at the beginning of "your hill" you do running training before the hill session itself .

Running training exercises you run on a 20 meter stretch up your hill. Rest once down. We start by doing one round of each exercise, "just introducing" the movement pattern.

1x20m av:

1. Low Skip

2. High Skip

3. Bouncing steps

4. Multistep

5. Heel kick each

(see video for the execution)

After the heel kick, your heart rate has picked up a bit and you can start your "hill".

Focus on finding the right pace and running "right on the hill".

The goal is to have about 60 seconds in the climb. (50-70 seconds ok). You run nicely and controlled uphill, and get a little tired. Stop and rest for a few seconds at the "top" or where you turn, then jog down leisurely to the start. Repeat and run a total of 17-19 minutes on the hill. In the "total time" you include both the run up and the jog down and also the small rest time at the top. (keep the clock ticking).

Unwind calmly as usual and stretch your muscles thoroughly because the running training and the hill have surely "contracted" your muscles a little extra.

The extra session for volume for the week's training. Ok to skip this session for rest or for any other training activities you have. The goal of 4.00 is "achievable" even without the Saturday session, although some weeks it is good to have the weekend's double session combination effect!

But as I said, listen to your body, and adapt to what you have time for!Prio to be eager for the program new "marathon thousands" tomorrow - physically and mentally!

Today we're going to run a new element of the program that the coach calls "marathon crunches", and it simply means that instead of a regular long run, you must accumulate long run volume by running many "calm" 1 km intervals.

In the long run volume that is created, we also count up and down by 2-3km.

So start the session with a few kilometers of leisurely running. Stop and do some mobility for your joints/ligaments and running muscles. If you want, you can also include some simple and softening running training exercises. Then you're ready to start your 1 km intervals.

A target speed might be to run around 25-35 seconds faster in minutes per kilometer than your normal long run pace. In order to get an optimal setup, you can advantageously start the first 1 km intervals a little slower/calmer than the specified "guide speed", so maybe "only" 20 seconds faster than the long pass pace, in order to then have the capacity to increase the speed a little afterwards and that the last The 1 km intervals will be the fastest - even though you then have the most volume in your legs.

We adjust the number of intervals based on how long the intervals take, so the faster the runner, the more intervals.

So for you with 4:00 as a time goal today we aim to run 16 x 1 km and the target speed after you get started will be Around 5:35 down to 5:25 min/km if we start from 6:00 min/km at long pass pace.

The rest between every "marathon tussle" you take a 45-60 second standing/walking rest.

Even if it's not a long session, you will be out for a long time with ups and downs, so feel free to bring a drink with you during the session, and especially today when you want to run faster, it may be time to drink energy at some of the rests or some energy gel. (or whatever you like)

Mentally; don't think about how many you have left at the beginning, but focus on your running technique, to run relaxed but still "active", because now you should have a slightly more active step than your normal long-pass step. After a while, there are "only" a few intervals left, and then you can start counting down!

After the last intervals, exhale before finishing the session with a few kilometers of calm deceleration and finished easy mobility for the running muscles that have had to work!

name: Training week 13
plan: Now we are almost halfway through the program towards the marathon. Hope everything feels ok, because here comes another tough week. TWO qualitative sessions and a record long session. If you are tired, you remove the Saturday session and if we are going to prioritize one of the quality sessions, this week will be the threshold session if you had a slope last week. If you remove the hill, make sure the running training is kept alive during one of the other sessions.

trainingDays.description: Now we are almost halfway through the program towards the marathon. Hope everything feels ok, because here comes another tough week. TWO qualitative sessions and a record long session. If you are tired, you remove the Saturday session and if we are going to prioritize one of the quality sessions, this week will be the threshold session if you had a slope last week. If you remove the hill, make sure the running training is kept alive during one of the other sessions.

3x10 minutes with 1.5 minutes standing/light jogging rest. Direction as before Around 5.25 min/km and then gives 10 minutes Around 1.8 km. You don't need to push harder than before, but the training unit is the one that will develop you!

As always, the feeling is more important than the target speed so find your speed between comfortable and uncomfortable quickly!!â€‹

Long hill and running training that you still have the feeling for the setup from last week?!

Warm up with a distance jog to a hill you know. The hill should not be "too steep" but nicely runnable all the way.

After the warm-up, you do some light mobility and then at the beginning of "your hill" you do running training before the hill session itself.

Running training exercises run you on a 20 meter stretch up your hill. Rest once down. We increase to 2x20 meters of all the exercises or if you think it's a lot, you choose exercise 2-4-5.

1x20m of:

1. Low Skip

2. High Skip

3. Bouncing steps

4. Multistep

5. Heel kick every

After the heel kick you have got your heart rate up a bit and can start your "hill".

Focus on finding the right pace and running "just right for the hill".

The goal is to have approx. 60 seconds in the uphill. (50-70 seconds ok). You run nicely and controlled uphill, and get a little tired. Stop and rest for a few seconds at the "top" or where you turn, then jog down leisurely to the start. Repeat and run a total of 17-19 minutes on the hill. In the "total time" you include both the run up and the jog down and also the small rest time at the top. (keep the clock rolling).
Easy distance and the strength of the week here.

The long pass is struggling with "pers" again. 25km today if everything feels good. Your calm speed, so no weirdness. Drink during/after and energy after. Good to now possibly also have some "energy out on the pass". Either in the form of a sports drink if you don't already do it, or in the form of something "sweet" that can raise the blood sugar a little at the end of the session!

name: Training week 14
plan:
3 sessions a week, which should be slightly easier, even if the amount is still good. 

Hill and marathon this week and then the long pass continues to a full 26 km now; assuming everything feels good to you. 

So a very good week, even if for some of you it probably feels like a little bit.â€‹

trainingDays.description:
3 sessions a week, which should be slightly easier even if the amount is still good.

Hill and marathon this week and then the long session continues to a full 26 km now; provided that everything feels good to you.

So a very good week even if for some of you it probably feels like a little bit..

The long back pass returns with the same setup as last week, but we increase it by 5 more minutes on the hill itself.

Warm-up jog, mobility and then the running training over 2x20m before the back pass start;

1. Low Skip

2. High Skip

3. Bouncing steps

4. Multistep

5. Heel kick every

On the hill focus on good steps; drive with the whole step and push off right from the "toes". RUN "FINE", as if someone is pulling your body "upward on a string" without losing the power forward...Difficult, but run!!

The hill gives, regardless of step, technique, a good workout for your steps and technique and also good cardio training!
You recognize the marathon pass and the strength. A bit faster than the distance and your rhythm to the marathon!â€‹
26 km at your leisurely pace for the day. The distance and the time out is the tough part, and not the speed. Drink along and energy and fluids after your roughly 2.5 hours today.

name: Training week 15
plan:
A somewhat adequate week, with 3-4 sessions depending on whether you want to go out for a quiet round on Saturday.

We start the week calmly with distance. On Thursday, there will be a threshold divided into 1 km sections and then we round off the week with a long long session again.

In the long session, add a speed increase part if everything feels good. Hopefully in some spring weather!

trainingDays.description:
A somewhat adequate week, with 3-4 sessions depending on whether you want to go out for a quiet round on Saturday.

We start the week calmly with distance. On Thursday, there will be a threshold divided into 1 km sections and then we round off the week with a long long session again.

In the long session, add a speed increase part if everything feels good. Hopefully in some spring weather!â€‹
Distance adjusted at speed according to how you feel today. No pressured session but a focus on supplementing the run with strength as usual for those of you who follow the program's strength.

Today we return to our threshold session, but today we run a harmonious session divided into 1 km sections. So threshold-thousands simply.

Then what is the difference to 1 km intervals? Well, the speed.

It shouldn't be a pressured session in terms of speed, but you should float along at a comfortable fast speed.

45 seconds standing or light jogging rest between each "threshold thumping".

Before the threshold start, we run as usual a warm-up with calm warm-up distance, followed by mobility. Short effective running training and pulse-raising coordination.

Then you start the threshold workout. Target image is 7 x 1 km and your target speed will be around 5.10-5.15 min/km at pace. Maybe start a little slower so you find harmony and then at the end you can push a little faster in return.

Unwind with a leisurely jog followed by stretch/mobility.

This week's extra session. Prioritize the long session tomorrow if you think it will be too tough with two sessions in a row or if you cannot find training time on the weekend for both sessions. But if there is time, the body is ok; run a nice quiet half hour that builds further foundation towards your mara!â€‹

Today we run a long session with an element of speed again. So no increase in time or kilometer length, but instead the focus is on getting in a speed section. If you already feel from the beginning of the session that it might be tough with speed today, then you skip the long speed section (the km parts) and only run the initial 30-45-60 seconds to change steps in your long session.

Start up the long pass at your usual speed and roll on to about half the distance of today's total distance goal. Decide where the speed element is based on where it fits into your round. The speed portion begins with 30 seconds of fast running, 1 minute easy, 45 seconds fast, 1 minute easy, 60 seconds fast and then 2 minutes easy. On these speed parts, the focus is that you should work with good technique and speed up your legs and get your heart rate up a bit. The layout should be your comfortably fast speed and no focus here to have any heading speed. Run with feeling, and run nicely. 

Come up to the step and try to run with a proud posture, and you will engage unused muscle power.

After 2 minutes of calm basic speed after the 60 second speed increase comes the main speed part where there will be a few kilometer speed parts.

The speed parts will be 3 km1 km1 km.

Guided speeds:

3 km 5.30-5.35 min/km.

1 km 5.10-5.15 min/km.

Between each km speed increase part, 2 minutes of calm long-pass basic speed or even calmer applies . (If you need to, you can walk a little bit in the 2 minute "rest part") On the last speed increase part, you can increase it even harder in the last minute of the km speed part. But not so fast that you risk injury.

After finishing the speed part, you take a 3-minute really calm jog or walk where you can take the opportunity to drink. However, do not stop for too long, but then start up again to your usual long-pass base speed and then complete the long pass so that you reach the day's distance goal.

name: Training week 16
plan:
New week and new challenges, where the weekend will be really tough if you run according to the program to the fullest.

Combining a fast distance (all Competition/PremiÃ¤rmilen) with a long session the next day is tough and actually a bit "over course".

So don't hesitate to modify the plan, shorten Sunday's long session to around 70-90 minutes, you drive hard on Saturday. Tune in with both the feeling in your body and how you feel mentally about the challenge.

If the coach is to guide the weekend's setup a bit, it will be:

1. Everything feels great and you are not tired; yes, test the program's layout!

2. Have you driven well with long sessions during the year; yes then you can focus on fast distance/races and then take Sunday as it comes with rest or shorter long sessions.

3. If you haven't gotten in as many long runs so far this year, then you prioritize running long distances for the weekend. Same if you like to really have regular long sessions; then of course you choose to run long this weekend as well!

But the training week doesn't just consist of the weekend, but work as well as you can in the week leading up to the weekend, and hopefully with a little spring in the air!

trainingDays.description:
New week and new challenges, where the weekend will be really tough if you run according to the program to the fullest.

Combining a fast distance (all Competition/PremiÃ¤rmilen) with a long session the next day is tough and actually a bit "over course".

So don't hesitate to modify the plan, shorten Sunday's long session to around 70-90 minutes, you drive hard on Saturday. Tune in with both the feeling in your body and how you feel mentally about the challenge.

If the coach is to guide the weekend's setup a bit, it will be:

1. Everything feels great and you are not tired; yes, test the program's layout!

2. Have you driven well with long sessions during the year; yes then you can focus on fast distance/races and then take Sunday as it comes with rest or shorter long sessions.

3. If you haven't gotten in as many long runs so far this year, then you prioritize running long distances for the weekend. Same if you like to really have regular long sessions; then of course you choose to run long this weekend as well!

But the training week doesn't just consist of the weekend, but work as well as you can in the week leading up to the weekend, and hopefully with a little spring in the air!

You let your body control the speed game and it's perfectly okay to let the session be easy.

You are welcome to "cheat a little" with the speed, and just flow through with small speed variations. Aim for shorter bursts of speed, from 30 seconds up to 2 minutes, but don't push too hard. Sometimes it can be nice to just float, and now feels like a good position, at least from the program's perspective. Complete with a full round of strength after the run.

A short back pass as a break from all distance/amount.

â€“ Good to shift the step a little and reach muscles you may not always activate so well in your running but which are good to keep moving so they can be activated when fatigue sets in longer runs!!

Warm up with a leisurely distance run to your short hill.

The hill should provide a nice counterslope, but no steeper than you can run with good strides uphill for 20-30 seconds.

A little softening movement when you arrive at the hill. Light running training, preferably in the opposite direction on the hill.

The short hill means that you run fast for 20-30 seconds up the hill. The rest between hills is a leisurely jog down, combined with a few seconds of standing rest at the top/turn and below the hill before starting the next hill.

Run with good pressure and try to maintain a good technical run. Drive so hard that you just feel a little lactic acid on top. It is important, however, that you run the first hill uphill a little more calmly, so you don't start with shock lactic acid in your legs. See the first slope as part of the warm-up. Find your pace and rhythm uphill. Run with a total time of around 15 minutes on the hill, all time including both running up/down and the standing short rest.

After the hill run, it is as usual important that you wind down with a leisurely jog followed by stretching.
\ nAre you running the ASICS Premier Mile or investing in a really tough training weekend; then you shorten the day to 5-8 short 20-30 s slopes with good steps!

Fast distance on the schedule today, and for those of you who live in the Stockholm area, you can use a virtual Premier Mile as your passport.

If you don't run the race, it is "enough" to run an 8 km fast distance, and you are welcome to use your test race round as you had previously in the program and see what you have "above your test 5km" and then add 3km directly to your 5th.

Target down to 5.05-5.10 speed, a little slower if the body doesn't really want it. In any case, as always, a harmonious start, but then you are welcome to mobilize mental strength to run really hard.

A shorter long session today, because the program's layout is based on the idea that today's long session should come in combination with a tougher fast distance yesterday.

Did you not run a little harder yesterday, and everything feels ok today, of course you can extend the session a bit if you want; or you still do "only" 22 km and give your body a somewhat calmer weekend!

name: Training week 17
plan:
Hope the training goes smoothly and that it is now facilitated by the fact that it is a little spring!!

A varied week in terms of training, as the coach includes, among other things, a hill pass with different lengths where you can work with different speeds and range of motion in your run based on the length of the hill . Thursday features foundational short intervals where you run your for-the-season comfortably fast pace; whatever you do will be a good transition to everything else.

Find your flow; and DO NOT push HARD on the short intervals.

Sunday the long session rolls on as usual and now with 28 km as the target; at your leisurely pace!

trainingDays.description:
Hope the training goes smoothly and that it is now facilitated by the fact that it is a little spring!!

A varied week in terms of training, as the coach includes, among other things, a hill pass with different lengths where you can work with different speeds and range of motion in your run based on the length of the hill . Thursday features foundational short intervals where you run your for-the-season comfortably fast pace; whatever you do will be a good transition to everything else.

Find your flow; and DO NOT push HARD on the short intervals.

Sunday the long session rolls on as usual and now with 28 km as the target; at your leisurely pace!

Today it will be downhill! First warm up with a distance jog that takes you to a hill that should ideally be long enough that you can get in up to 60 seconds of running uphill at a comfortably fast pace. Fairly steep so you can run the entire 60-second stretch uphill at an ok speed.

Once in place at the hill, you do some mobility and running training.

Running training; 2 x 20 meters in the bottom counterslope of the hill.

Basic exercises; low skip - high knee lift heel kicks and then you can if you want to add any more exercise (check out the video). Walking rest down the running training distance. Think about good posture and active steps.

Then we start the downhill session itself, and it will be a session where we will work with both longer and shorter slopes.

The purpose of the session will be to work on running technique, running strength and fitness but also a little different "pressure in the step" during the session.

We start with some 60 second (takes approx. 60 seconds uphill) long hills where we work with good technique but without pushing too much. We run "nice and controlled" uphill.

Good to take the first long hill as part of the warm-up.

When we then switch to an intermediate variant in the time uphill, it will be a 40-second running time uphill and now you try to increase the pressure in the step a notch but not tougher than that on the closing short "20 second downhills" we can increase pressure, range of motion and posture another notch.

The rest between the slopes is that you stop and rest for a few seconds where we turn, and then we jog down to the start and take a few seconds' rest before starting again.

On the longer slopes, the jog down can preferably be a little faster, but on the shorter slopes, the jog down can be really calm and preferably also a little the beginning and end of "the transport is brought down".

Between the changes of the hill length, you can also take a few seconds of extra standing rest below the hill so that you are ready to push a notch more on the next variation of the hill length.

Your target picture today will be to run the following number of hills in the respective time length up:

4 x 60 seconds

5 x 40 seconds

5 x 20 seconds

After the hill run, you wind down with a leisurely jog followed by some form of stretching.

Start today's session with a warm-up distance at a leisurely pace of around 2.5 km, followed by short softening mobility. Then a running training component with some exercises over 2 x 30 meters. Also feel free to do some coordination to get your pulse and speed up before the interval part starts.

The layout of the interval session will be 200 meter intervals, divided into series with 4 intervals in each series. The rest is 30 seconds of "standing rest" between intervals, and then you take 60 seconds of standing/walking rest between each set. The goal picture will be 16 intervals in total, so 4 x 4 x 200 meters.

Really short rest today, which means that the speed should not be pressured or high, but the short rest ensures a good conditioning effect and transfer to your marathon pace will be included supermarginal :)

The program (and you) should continue to focus on foundational cardio training, but the goal is of course also to get your legs moving without risking injuries through running too fast.

Run through the session with "one gear left" , and focus on your technique. Good stately posture and active step. Let the drive of the arms help with the speed without being tempted to sprint for the sake of it!

Target speed around 4.10-4.15 min/km, which gives around 50-51 seconds per 200 meters.

End the session as usual with jogging mobility.

To get the week's strength in, we run a separate home session without running. Light easy warm-up "around the house", bicycle or other, and then a little lighter strength than usual just to keep the muscles moving and not lose the continuity we built up through strength every week.

26 km long pass. Long but still not maxed out in distance and only your relatively "calm" long pass speed for the day. Shorten if the body is worn. The whole is most important - and we have several more weekends to work on the long pass foundation before the marathon.

name: Training week 18
plan:
Tough week again, even if it is limited to 3 training sessions. However, the beginning of the week should be relatively easy, with the marathon session which, although it adds volume, should not be too tiring. The intervals can be a tough session, but remember not to go too hard there at the beginning.

At the weekend, the session returns with "marathon tweeners" where the target image is a full 18 x 1 km. If it feels too tough, then you can convert the session into a regular long session at your basic speed and aim to run 23-25 km in total.

trainingDays.description:
Tough week again, even if it is limited to 3 training sessions. However, the beginning of the week should be relatively easy, with the marathon session which, although it adds volume, should not be too tiring. The intervals can be a tough session, but remember not to go too hard there at the beginning.

At the weekend, the session returns with "marathon tweeners" where the target image is a full 18 x 1 km. If it feels too tough, then you can convert the session into a regular long session at your basic speed and aim to run 23-25 km in total.
Efter kort uppvÃ¤rmning; lite snabbare Ã¤n distansen och din rytmen till maran!

Today we run here with the program a combination interval session with long and short intervals. We will repeat the interval series 2 x 3 minutes followed by 4 x 40 seconds As usual before the speed part of the session you start with a warm-up run. Let the warm-up take you to your inspiring interval stretch. You can run the intervals back and forth on the same distance, but of course you can also "graze" the intervals forward on your round. If you want, it is also very good to run the session on the treadmill, and then you can even start from a fixed distance on the intervals and let the time be around 3 minutes on "your long" and around 40 seconds on your short intervals. Regardless of where you run the intervals, however, the interval distance should not be too hilly; and there will be a hump; you adjust the speed and do not chase average speed. When you have warmed up with your leisurely run, do some dynamic mobility and preferably also some warm-up and running training exercises. Then you finish the warm-up part with a coordination run/increase run. Then you are ready for the intervals, where you can start from the "guidelines" but your feeling is most important and then it is important that you find a good flow in the "long" 3 minute intervals while at the same time allowing ourselves some fatigue. In the 40 second intervals, you can dare to step up even more and really work well with your speed. Rest is 1 minute standing/walking between and after the 3 minute intervals and then 40 seconds standing/walking after each 40 second interval. When you have run a full series of 2 x 3 minutes followed by 4 x 40 seconds, you take a series rest of around 1-1.5 minutes. Here you decide how long you need to recharge. The target image here with the program will be the following arrangement: 2 SERIES where each series contains 2 x 3 minutes followed by 4 x 40 seconds. 1 SET of 1 x 3 minutes followed by 2 x 40 seconds. (Total interval time 21:40 min) 3 minute target speed: 4.40 min/km. Gives about 640 meters per interval. 40 second target speed: 4.06 min/km. Gives about 165 meters per interval. Round off with a leisurely downhill jog!

Today, the session that the coach calls "marathon thousand" returns. We had it in the program at the end of February, and now we are running again and also adding two "Marathon tweens".

The pass means that you must accumulate long-pass volume by running many "calm" 1 km intervals. In the long-pass volume that is created, we also include a warm-up of 2-3 km and a cool-down of 2-3 km.

So start the session with a leisurely run for a few kilometers. Stop and do some mobility for your joints/ligaments and running muscles. If you want, you can also include some simple and softening running training exercises. Then you're ready to start your 1 km intervals.

The goal is to run around 30-40 seconds faster in minutes per kilometer than your normal long run pace.

Optimize your setup by starting the first 1 km intervals a little slower/calmer than the specified "guide speed", so that you can then increase the speed a little later and that the last 1 km interval will be the fastest - even though you then have the most volume in your legs.

For you with a fast 4:00 who time goal is the goal of 18 x 1 km and the target speed after you get started will be around 5:30-5:20 min/km if we start from 6:00 at a long pass pace.

The rest between each "Maraton tussing" you take 60 seconds standing /walking rest.

Bring drinks out on the pass, and maybe even some energy gel. (or anything else you like with energy)

Mental; think positively and that you actually get to rest, which you don't get during the long session as regularly as now. Take it one step at a time, and look forward to the feeling you get when you've done 18 reps!

After the 18th interval, you exhale before finishing the session with a few kilometers of calm deceleration and finished easy mobility for the running muscles that have had to work!

name: Training week 19
plan: A slightly calmer start to the week may be needed, so take a maximum of 6 km there so you can bring home all the training done and to come. Because the rest of the week and the coming weeks are tough. Be responsive and remove/lighten passports if you need to. The fast distance is long; and tough and late for the weekend, you skip the short downhill section if you are tired. More important to get the long pass.

trainingDays.description: A slightly calmer start to the week may be needed, so take a maximum of 6 km there so you can bring home all the training done and to come. Because the rest of the week and the coming weeks are tough. Be responsive and remove/lighten passports if you need to. The fast distance is long; and tough and late for the weekend, you skip the short downhill section if you are tired. More important to get the long pass.
Lugn distans!

Fast Distance Pass. If everything feels good, you can be spurred on by pushing the time, and hopefully it will go a little faster now than at the beginning of our training program. Target image around 5.00 min/km at speed.

However, think about the whole of your training where no single session must be too hard. Worn out; Run through without a time ambition, and above all let the body get into the session through a slightly softer introduction to your 7 km fast distance.

Extra sessions that you only include in your total if you feel energetic, and you feel that you responded well to the program's training. Calm distance of 3+3 km where you stop during the round (in the proposal after 3 km and the distance is written as warm-up and jog down) ) and put in a 5x100 meter short hill with a springy step.

Take a little rest up/down (5 -10 s) and have a calm jog downhill as your rest as well.

Focus on getting a little pressure uphill without getting really tired!

Good combo with the long session IF you are physically fit in general!

A record for the program. Adapt to your feeling! Shorten it if it feels too tough.

Bring drinks; and time to start testing your energy plan for the marathon!

name: Training week 20
plan:
A week where we focus on Thursday's interval training and then a slightly shorter long training session for the weekend to keep the long training feeling going and at the same time give the body a chance to absorb all the tough training - and be ready for the last really tough weeks of the program including our two longest training sessions. So shorter now - to be able to gear up a notch to later.

Are you running the Premier Half on Saturday?, well then you change the week and skip the long session and take the race as your tough training this weekend!

Thursday's speed session would you be able to sleep on Tuesday, then you just go for a leisurely jog on Thursday before the race!

trainingDays.description:
A week where we focus on Thursday's interval training and then a slightly shorter long training session for the weekend to keep the long training feeling going and at the same time give the body a chance to absorb all the tough training - and be ready for the last really tough weeks of the program including our two longest training sessions. So shorter now - to be able to gear up a notch to later.

Are you running the Premier Half on Saturday?, well then you change the week and skip the long session and take the race as your tough training this weekend!

Thursday's speed session would you be able to sleep on Tuesday, then you just go for a leisurely jog on Thursday before the race!
Calm distance of approx. 8km to just keep feeling and volume in the training. Keep in mind that the end of the week will be tough, so a calm "entertainingÂ¨" start to the week is good enough.

Today we will run an interval ladder where we increase the speed the shorter the intervals become. First, we warm up as usual with a leisurely distance jog that takes you to your interval distance. Aim to get to a stretch/round where you can get in 3 minutes of interval speed running without too much hilling.

After the warm-up calm run, you first do some mobility and then we put in the week's running training. Run your exercises as you like, and with a range of motion adapted to you and your habit of running training. Then round off the warm-up with two pulse-raising coordination runs and then 1-2 minutes of rest before starting the interval part.

We run an interval-setup a little adapted so that you could run this together with one/some running buddies, even if you are at different levels. Because then you/you can run "forward/backward" on the same distance as the interval steps we will run constantly repeat an interval length twice. (Forward + backward will make you always end up in the same place after every second interval regardless of level)
 
Riding alone or with a friend, you can of course drive the session forward on a lap if it feels more stimulating than the forward/back layout.

Regardless of the layout, the goal is that you work at a higher speed the shorter the interval time/distance. Keep in mind, however, that in the initial 3 minutes you take it "just right" so you find the right fit in the session.

We rest the same throughout the session of 1 minute standing/walking between each interval.

The layout of the interval steps will be: 

The interval steps: 2 x 3 min â€“ 2 x 2 min â€“ 2 x 1 min followed by 2 x 2 min â€“ 2 x 1 min

12 + 6 minutes, a total of 18 minutes of interval time. (In time approx. 4 km)

Directional speeds:

3 minutes: 4.39 min/km in time approx. 645m

2 minutes: 4.25 min/km in time approx. 450m

1 minute: 4.15 min/km in time approx. 235m 

After the interval part, you round off as usual with a downhill jog and stretch.
Calm down just come out and run passes. Time on your own or a chat with a friend.

Calm long run - with a slightly shorter distance to give some breathing space before we move on with two more really long long runs in the final phase towards the marathon.

26 km at your comfortable long run speed for the day - keeps everything going - and gives the body a chance to absorb all tough training!

Bring a drink to the session, and if you have the opportunity - try taking energy at some point during the session to "train" it before the marathon and to have a good energy level during the session!

name: Training week 21
plan:
The training program continues, and if you are tired from the recent tough training, it may be time to "pulse down this week".

To make the week a little easier, you can remove or shorten sessions and then hopefully you are then both keen on and receptive to a really long session on Sunday - a session that is the week's focus session provided you are not "too tired".

If everything goes smoothly, then you can drive, of course you can drive the week in full; and then a good back pass can be suitable for both running strength, running technique and cardio training!

trainingDays.description:
The training program continues, and if you are tired from the recent tough training, it may be time to "pulse down this week".

To make the week a little easier, you can remove or shorten sessions and then hopefully you are then both keen on and receptive to a really long session on Sunday - a session that is the week's focus session provided you are not "too tired".

If everything goes smoothly, then you can drive, of course you can drive the week in full; and then a good back pass can be suitable for both running strength, running technique and cardio training!

Warm-up followed by five sets of fifteen/fifteen as we had once before. Running at a fast but controlled pace for 15 seconds and then resting for 15 seconds. So you repeat this 5 times in each series.

A total of 5 series in today's session and the rest between each series is 1-2 minutes standing/walking-around rest. You will probably get around 1.5 km, but the important thing is, as before, NOT the volume, but that you work with speed and the step, which is the focus. Run as fast as you can keeping in mind that you will start immediately after 15 seconds again. Run forward/backward or forward on a stretch.

Round off today's session with the week's strength and thorough mobility.

Today the plan is for us to run a combination variant with both some long but also short slopes. For volume for the pass, we take a distance warm-up of 3 km. Then the running training before the back start. On the hill, we run by number instead of time, but make a short estimate that it will take around 17-18 minutes and will be at least 2 km in total. The set-up will be 3x60 second hills, followed by 4x40 seconds and ending on the hill with 4x20 second hills. The time indicated in the uphill and rest between each hill is a light jog down the hill and a 5-10 second standing rest at the "up" and "down" turns. Try to come up with a plan where the long hills go in at a speed where you can run "nice" and without getting completely exhausted. Work harder on the 40-second hill and then on the 20-second hill, I hope the hill is short enough that you can bounce uphill with good pressure. The choice of slope is based on the assumption that you will be able to handle the slope on the long slope, so do not choose a slope that is "too steep".

Record-long long pass. 31 km if everything goes smoothly

Important to be responsive to the signals; tired, yes, then you shorten today's long session. Drink, during and after and energy during and after the session!!

name: Training week 22
plan:
Intermediate week with speed and recovery long session.

Focus on giving the body a slightly calmer training and getting in short intervals (without speed that risks any damage). The feeling of long workouts is of course good to maintain - but the coach intends to make it shorter this year so you can recharge for the following week's longest long workoutsâ€‹

trainingDays.description:
Intermediate week with speed and recovery long session.

Focus on giving the body a slightly calmer training and getting in short intervals (without speed that risks any damage). The feeling of long workouts is of course good to maintain - but the coach intends to make it shorter this year so you can recharge for the following week's longest long workouts
Short, calm distance and strength may start the week. You will get far on Sunday; so settle for 5 km today!!

You recognize the short intervals. The last time where you run 15 pieces of 200 meters.

Target slightly faster than the last time if you have a good day. So a little under 4.00 pace and thus under 48 seconds per 200 meters.

We keep the rest at 45 s between intervals and 90 s between series.

Float, but still a little pressure in the step on the last series. Allow yourself to be tired....if you have an ok day!

Try the marathon setup, with a short jog, mobility and two light coordinations the day before a long session! See if this feels good or if, for example, the complete rest day that you had during other long sessions gave/gives you a better effect! Then you know what to do when the time comes...

The program breaks off with a slightly shorter long session. If a long session can feel short?

The session maintains your long session feeling, but hopefully gives the body a chance to absorb all the training.

Coach Szalkai wants this slightly shorter long session to now give you a small "buffer" both mentally and physically before the upcoming last tough part of the program - before the tapering starts towards the marathon, which is now only less than 4 weeks away.

So calm base speed and a little shorter, but of course with the usual long-pass advice where drink/energy is included and that you be careful after the session with dry clothes and new energy in so you don't open up to catching an unnecessary cold now!

name: Training week 23
plan:
A good week with a really tough finish. The goal is to squeeze in a 34 km round for the weekend.

- Good for many mentally to take with you, but if you have done a good long session before, you absolutely do not stand and fall with Sunday's session, but if you are tired, it is completely ok to shorten. You can also skip Saturday's session if you want and feel it is necessary to work towards + 30k the next day.

Other than that, we work with a little speed this week through Thursday's short hill and a marathon session as an introduction which you can shorten to 5-8 km if 10 km feels long just for the day.

trainingDays.description:
A good week with a really tough finish. The goal is to squeeze in a 34 km round for the weekend.

- Good for many mentally to take with you, but if you have done a good long session before, you absolutely do not stand and fall with Sunday's session, but if you are tired, it is completely ok to shorten. You can also skip Saturday's session if you want and feel it is necessary to work towards + 30k the next day.

Other than that, we work with a little speed this week through Thursday's short hill and a marathon session as an introduction which you can shorten to 5-8 km if 10 km feels long just for the day.

The marathon pass one last time in our long version. Sufficiently tough, and if you are tired, remove or lighten up to a calm 10-12 km round. Prioritize that you get into the hill with a little springy step on Thursday and then that you are charged for the program's longest long run next Sunday.

Warm up as usual with jogging, mobility and the running training exercises.

The hill should be a "slightly steeper version" but you should be able to run with good strides and be able to last around 20-25 seconds in the uphill and feel a little lactic acid in your legs on top". Take a few (5-10) seconds of rest both at the turning point of your short hill and before starting the next hill. Focus on a good step with good drive. Work well with slightly faster arm movements and good knee assignments if it comes reasonably naturally to you. No completely unfamiliar movements now...

Important to unwind with a calm jog and stretch!

Easy extra pass that really is extra. Of course gives good effect with tomorrow's pass; but pass no injury or overtraining limits now to get this pass. Only for those of you who feel like you're soaking up all the training right now! Prioritize tomorrow...

The program's longest long session!

Really long, and inevitably over 3 hours. YOUR CALM SPEED, and it's ok to slow down a notch more than you usually do to complete the distance!

Make sure you load up with some extra carbohydrates the day before, and bring drinks with you on the run. (feel free to try the sports drink if you haven't done it before) Test your intended competition shoes, and see that they work with your feet all the way.

It is extremely important that you are careful after the session, with energy, drink and dry clothes so that you do not the situation we're in now will catch you with an unnecessary cold.

-Make sure you get an hour's rest after the session, and don't have to do so much before the body has had time to recover a little at least!

name: Training week 24
plan:
Now begins our tapering off for this year's ASICS Stockholm Marathon.

Now it is more about starting to find flow and the rhythm than "moving forward" so much on the individual sessions.

Have you managed to follow the program broadly, I think you're doing well and now you're making a lot of money by starting to reduce your training.

Starting with some much-needed quiet days, after last week's tough overall and tough long sessions. If you want, you can shorten the Tuesday session to an even shorter leisurely jog.

This week's tough session will be the fast distance. There you can go hard if everything feels ok.

Long session at a leisurely pace, but for those who feel that the body has responded well to recent training, you can add a good increase in speed to the session.

Last chance also to in the long session moment try maran's sports drink. -So you haven't done it before; test now and see if it works; also applies to shoes and clothes. Try out what you'll wear on the maran!

Good luck with the week!

trainingDays.description:
Now begins our tapering off for this year's ASICS Stockholm Marathon.

Now it is more about starting to find flow and the rhythm than "moving forward" so much on the individual sessions.

Have you managed to follow the program broadly, I think you're doing well and now you're making a lot of money by starting to reduce your training.

Starting with some much-needed quiet days, after last week's tough overall and tough long sessions. If you want, you can shorten the Tuesday session to an even shorter leisurely jog.

This week's tough session will be the fast distance. There you can go hard if everything feels ok.

Long session at a leisurely pace, but for those who feel that the body has responded well to recent training, you can add a good increase in speed to the session.

Last chance also to in the long session moment try maran's sports drink. -So you haven't done it before; test now and see if it works; also applies to shoes and clothes. Try out what you'll wear on the maran!

Good luck with the week!
Easy distance and last strength fully; next week there will be less strength in your deceleration in terms of training and escalation in terms of form towards the marathon.

Fast distance of 5 km. It can be a tough, really tough session, but with a focus on fluidity in running. If you feel more like threshold speed, choose it. Marathon speed can also be enough...Let the day's form decide and keep in mind that we save the last bit to pick out the body for the marathon.

Those of you who are part of TSM Running can run the fast distance on the "MilspÃ¥ret", either 5 or 10 km which is the official test run for TSM Running.

The program's and perhaps your last long pass before the marathon, will be a 24 km pass at mostly calm long pass speed. During a section over about 4 km, you can increase your speed to well below your intended marathon race speed to get a final test and push your long-pass motor!

Enter your speed increase after about 60 minutes of running and try to run faster for about 22 minutes . Finish image at a speed of around 5.30 min/km.

If you are tired and your body is not responding; run calmly all the way through.

As always important drink, and energy and more fluids even afterwards for good and important recovery!

Regarding if this is your last long session before the marathon, you can actually if you missed many long sessions, put in a short leisurely long session with a week to go before the race instead of specified training. (Then removes Sunday's schedule where it is in the program).

name: Training week 25
plan:
One more step down in volume to give the body even more chance to create a top shape. Two of this week's sessions contain good quality aspects for the form.

Oxygen uptake, endurance at high speed and flow via short intervals on Thursday. Flexible and running technique via the hill and some short marathon flow there as well in the week's final session.

To keep the feeling going, we add two lighter distance sessions, where you can easily remove the Saturday session if you know that running rest usually gives a good effect directly to light legs. But if you feel; ok to jog on... Mentally; slowly begin to look forward to the goals of the entire training plan. Only one week away!!

Good luck with the week, it's getting close!!

trainingDays.description:
One more step down in volume to give the body even more chance to create a top shape. Two of this week's sessions contain good quality aspects for the form.

Oxygen uptake, endurance at high speed and flow via short intervals on Thursday. Flexible and running technique via the hill and some short marathon flow there as well in the week's final session.

To keep the feeling going, we add two lighter distance sessions, where you can easily remove the Saturday session if you know that running rest usually gives a good effect directly to light legs. But if you feel; ok to jog on... Mentally; slowly begin to look forward to the goals of the entire training plan. Only one week away!!

Good luck with the week, it's getting close!!
Easy distance of "only" 5km supplemented with two easy coordination runs and the last strength of the program where we also lighten up. - Everything to evoke a light feeling! Exercise but less!!

Usual warm-up before quality, including running training. 2x30m; 4 exercises; Low Skip-High Skip-Multistep-Heel Kick each. - Short interval sessions, where we now reduce the length of our interval slightly and run 3x4x200m, with 45 sec rest between intervals and 90 seconds between series. That is, 4 intervals with 45 sec rest, and then 90 sec rest before you run 4 more, etc. Target speed is around 45-47 sec per 200m (3.45-3.55 pace), Important, however, more flow/harmony is to push max. With 12 intervals, you have time to get good training both muscularly and for fitness! Relax calmly with jogging/stretching.
Calm any short distance. Only for those of you who think it would be nice to go out for a little round. If you can't get the hill/short threshold in tomorrow; put it here today.

We "check off the passes", and here comes a last resilience-giving back pass together with short threshold flow. In addition to working with good strides, the hill always maintains your fitness in a superb way and with the threshold you can float on in a little "sub marathon" Warm-up jog of 2km, then the mini running training in the opposite slope. 1x20m; Low Skip-High Skip-Multistep-Heel Kick each. Then the short hill, with a focus on good strides and getting "fairly tired". 8-10 slopes that take around 25 seconds up, and easy walking/jogging down. Take rest time "down" so the step up will be good!! After the hill you rest a bit and if necessary you move with a light jog to a stretch where you can float at sub marathon speed for 2 km. Much like the speed increase on the long pass, but without it being in a long pass. Find the flow and feel that the passion is finally here!!

name: Training week 26
plan: This week's training is completely aimed at optimizing you mentally and physically for Saturday. A few float intervals and easy entertaining distance. Both the intervals and Wednesday's distance workout can be included as a whole in your carbohydrate load. Carbohydrate loading may look a little different. The simplest is to "just" from Wednesday eat and drink extra carbohydrate-rich food/liquid up to and including Friday. A slightly more "advanced" variant is to lightly empty the body of carbohydrates on Tuesday and Wednesday morning before the actual storage starts on Wednesday. - It happens that on Tuesday you change your diet to include some carbohydrates (eat salad, protein and fat instead) while doing your interval training. The idea is then that the muscles are emptied of carbohydrates, and then you start Wednesday with a run before breakfast (morning jog) which also "empties". One theory is that the emptied muscles react to the emptying by being able to store some extra energy. I think the emptying itself also has a mental aspect by telling the body that you are approaching something special; MARAN! - After the Wednesday session, your charging starts by now starting to redirect your diet to contain a lot of carbohydrates. Eat a little extra at each meal, but don't overeat. Supplement with extra snacks on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday and treat yourself to some good carbohydrate content! Also supplement the "eating" with drinking all the time so that the extra energy can be stored in your muscles. Charging takes place on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, then well on the day of the competition you must be fully charged. NOTE; do not drain if you have a cold or feel sensitive; then you just run the charging and don't risk getting sick because the emptying initially makes you more susceptible to bacteria etc) If you were able to follow the training plan decently, you should take with you that you are WELL prepared. - Good luck with the week and then of course with the race!! /coach Szalkai

Both the intervals and Wednesday's distance workout can be included as a whole in your carbohydrate load. Carbohydrate loading may look a little different. Eat a little extra at each meal, but don't overeat. Supplement with extra snacks on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday and treat yourself to some good carbohydrate content! Also supplement the "eating" with drinking all the time so that the extra energy can be stored in your muscles. Charging takes place on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, then well on the day of the competition you must be fully charged. NOTE; do not drain if you have a cold or feel sensitive; then you just run the charging and don't risk getting sick because the emptying initially makes you more susceptible to bacteria etc) If you were able to follow the training plan decently, you should take with you that you are WELL prepared. - Good luck with the week and then of course with the race!! /coach Szalkai

A final speed session for body and bud. Can feel a bit tough, especially if today you "walk around" on a low-carbohydrate diet.

Try to focus on the flow of your run, and run tired, but certainly not too hard. You must have resources saved after the session, you save these for Saturday.

The purpose of the session is to maintain the feeling of running and that the intervals give the body both muscularly and centrally (heart lungs) a good "entertaining effect".

The session then; Two series with 4 200m or 45 second intervals. 2x4x200m or 2x4x45-50 seconds. The rest is 45 seconds between the intervals and 90 seconds after the 4th interval.

Easy, easy running training in your warm-up, with low skip, medium high skip and heel kick.

It is important that you cool down calmly, and stretch out the muscles.

Easy distance running 9km today, or if you follow the carbohydrate-loading scheme a "morning jog" of 9km. If you've never run before breakfast before and are trying it now, remember to take it really easy before you warm up your muscles and get started. It's perfectly fine to run the session later in the day, and then start your carbohydrate load towards the marathon!

Light jogging or complete rest. The jog is only for you who feel that the body and the bud need to air out a little. Not so great practical significance more than just for the feeling. You can feel a little heavy from the carbohydrate load and then a short jog can feel good, not least mentally. If you want, you add light mobility and two short movement coordinations at a comfortably fast speed.

Now we are at the final goal of the program.

Finally you will get all the training you put in, and I absolutely believe that if you have followed the program properly it will go really well!!

But it is a tough job that must be done, and you are set for it!

Start 12.00 or 12.10, so I think you eat your usual breakfast, but maybe not with so much fiber if you usually have fiber breakfast. No need for there to be lumps in the stomach!

Feel free to supplement breakfast with some extra carbohydrate.

Maybe a little sports drink including salt in the early morning, especially if it's hot!

Then if you are used to eating close to the long run, you can also take something light extra at 10.00-10.30; then food energy can wait until after/during the race.

Make sure everything is ready, with shoes, number tag etc.

Warm up a little before the start in the place in your starting line or a short jog before entering the starting line. Feel free to drink water until just before the start, then when you're up and running you can take a sport drink if you know it works for your stomach.

The start goes; do not stress. You'll make it, stress kills energy!

Find your slightly tougher long run pace (or medium hard distance pace), and break the race into smaller sections, both mentally and physically.

Buildings and buddies can be the split or simply every fluid check !

Take the liquid right from the first check.

YOU WILL DO IT if you are whole and healthy and have managed to follow the program reasonably well.

If you have followed the time decently on the sessions, 3.59 or faster is also within you if they the external conditions for running are OK on the day of the competition.

Of course it is tough, you have to be prepared that it does not come by itself but that you have to work when it takes.

Take help from the audience, fellow competitors and defeat any slumps!! Change step; work extra with your arms if you get into a slump!!

Think positively, and think that now is the time for all the training to "get out"!!

See you at the Stadium.

GOOD LUCK from coach Anders Szalkai.
